Scrape it into a separate empty large bowl and fold it with a rubber spatula until no big chunks of frozen ricotta remain. what do I put the ricotta ball into? bowl What should I do after I finish forming the gnudi sphere? Transfer it to the baking dish. What to do with the leftover semolina in the bowl? Sprinkle any remaining semolina in the bowl over the formed gnudi. what is the remaining semolina in? bowl how often should I turn a refrigerated gnudi? once per day What can I do if I am not ready to cook the gnudi immediately? They can be frozen. Transfer to a large plate or a rimmed baking sheet and freeze until solid, about 1 hour. Transfer to a zipper-lock freezer bag and store in the freezer for up to 2 months. Allow to thaw on a plate covered with plastic wrap in the refrigerator overnight before cooking. how long do I freeze gnudi for? about 1 hour what needs to subside before I stop heating butter? foaming what do I heat the butter in? medium saucepan What comes immediately after heating the butter in the saucepan?
target_answer: Add sage leaves, season lightly with salt, and cook, turning the leaves occasionally, until crisp, about 2 minutes.

Reduce speed to medium-low, add the sugar all at once, and mix only until well combined. what should I remove from the mixer? bowl what ingredients should I add next? eggs how should I mix the eggs? whisk How should I handle any clots of chalazae that remain trapped in the strainer? target_answer: Loosen the sides of the cheesecake from the pan with a thin knife or offset spatula. Place the pan on a large can of tomatoes or a similarly sized object; something tall enough to lift the cheesecake 4-inches from the counter, and wide enough to form a stable base. With both hands on the sides of the pan, pull downward to drop the outer ring away from the bottom. Place the cake onto a flat work surface, loosen it from the bottom of the pan with an offset spatula, and transfer to a large, flat serving plate.

target_answer: Loosen the sides of the cheesecake from the pan with a thin knife or offset spatula. Stand the cake in a few inches of scalding hot water until the pan feels warm (a roasting pan works well for this). Drape the cake in plastic wrap to protect its surface, then invert onto a large, flat plate, and lift the pan to pull it away. It should slide free without any resistance; if not, continue standing in hot water a few minutes more. After removing the pan, peel the parchment from the crust, and re-invert the cheesecake onto a serving plate.

target_answer: Combine the fresh fruit and warmed fruit syrup or jam in a large bowl, and gently fold with a flexible spatula until the fruit is well coated and glistening (optional). Cut the cheesecake with a large chef's knife dipped in hot water; for clean and tidy portions of cheesecake, pause to clean the blade under hot running water between each slice. Top with spoonfuls of the sauced fruit, if using, or other toppings and sauces as desired.
